author: Jacky Alcine
message:
Awesome! Ever considered making external source imports for Akregator like from Feedly or what not? I'm guessing it's not done because Akregator doesn't have a plug-in system for feed sources.

It'd be a bit like how Amarok can pull music from Google Music, Last.fm and other sources.

replies.author: Aurélien Gâteau
replies.message: Thanks! There is a akonadi_port of Akregator which brings something close to what you want. I haven't tried it yet, but I have been told it already has tinytinyrss support.

replies.author: Jacky Alcine
replies.message: That's quite interesting. I've been moving away from the browser to desktop apps and the only thing left was really just the RSS reader. Time to flex those C++ muscles, haha!

replies.author: Ernesto Manríquez
replies.message: I was going to ask what happened to Akregator2.

author: tanghus
message:
Great! I deeply appreciate every fix made to Akregator, as I use it every day, all of the day. Yes, I procrastinate a lot ;)
The #2 issue that bothers me most, is that I have to open an external browser to get the feed URL of a site I have browsed to in the internal browser.
#1 is that it crashed frequently when using webkit, but that seems to be the qtwebkit version shipped with (K)ubuntu. Maybe time to try KHTML again.

author: ChallisTowerBks
message:
Akregator is part of my daily routine too, so thanks for the fixes Aurelien! While everyone rushes around madly trying to find a substitute to Google Reader, my life remains calm and serene. :)

Kaz Augustin

author: Boudewijn Rempt
message: Awesome! I have wondered for so long why ongoing was broken, but I always was too lazy to try and figure it out :-)

author: Tom
message: Very kind of you, thanks. I use Akregator daily too (espaecailly too read the Planet KDE feed :). Most obvious bug to me is, that "Back" & "Forward" neither work in the context menu nor in the toolbar icons nor the shortcuts (alt+left/right), BUT backspace works...
